Normally yes -- but if we manage to move all of our timestamps to nanoseconds, we can drop the custom class entirely, so it might make sense to minimize what we put there.
Perhaps the most used method should be named `startSpan`/`endSpan`. The current `startSpan` could be renamed `startRawSpan` or something else. That way the instrumentation code is a bit shorter.

With that we need to reset the global trace provider in the OTLPFixture as this can normally only be done once.

A forked ubuntu theme or a new theme will have the same path requirements for the folder structure in a tgz file to be attached as a juju resource. The static path should exist always, the img path makes sense for the simple customizations and forked ubuntu theme, as the images are referenced in the _*.scss files. Maybe what you are saying is that I should make it clear that part of the structure in my example is just an example ? (like the presence of _*.scss file and image file names) Could you please clarify?

README.md.message:
may or will?

the commit message says "will"

both are correct in my interpretation:

In README: it may override any adjustments that would have been made. If adjustments have been made, generally speaking it *may* override. If the changes are specifically different than the default templates, then they *will* be overridden.

In commit message: *will* reapply the default templates, so if there were any changes, they *may* get overridden depending on what the changes are, and *will* get overridden if the changes per se are changes that differ from the default templates. In Wallaby+, it *will* also override any attribute that differs from the default template, if there are any changes. I could have said that it *may* override, generally speaking, depending on the changes.

src/charm.py.message: I don't think we need to have peers in this this - its an implicit relation so will never be missing!

relation_handlers_ready() checks if all the relation handlers mentioned in mandatory_relations are ready or not [1] before proceeding with bootstrap process.
Even though peers is an implicit relation, it should be mentioned either in mandatory_relations list or add in relation_handlers_ready() to check for peer relations as well. In this patch former approach is taken.

This is not a problem for rest of sunbeam charms because peer relation (and corresponding relation data) is not required to bootstrap and start the service in the unit. 
Where as in ovn-central-k8s charm, peer relation is required even if it is a single unit as the templates to write configurations uses information from the peer handler methods (even though the information is local unit one) [2] [3].
  
To summarize, peer handlers need not be ready to bootstrap for rest of sunbeam charms but not the case for ovn-central-k8s.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/charm-ops-sunbeam/src/branch/main/ops_sunbeam/charm.py#L313
[2] https://opendev.org/x/charm-ovn-central-k8s/src/branch/main/src/templates/ovn-nb-cluster-join.sh.j2#L13
[3] https://pastebin.ubuntu.com/p/Z4GG43bWfr/

Marking this as resolved, the current patchset deletes the opts files.

dnsmasq will not remove the in-memory configuration when a file is truncated, or if one or more entries is removed from a file. It has no knowledge of what was previously in the specific file, and thus does not know what configuration entry to remove. We need to HUP dnsmasq for this to take effect.

The snippet in dnsmasq manual that describes this:
  --dhcp-hostsdir=<path>
      <snip>
      If a file is deleted or changed after it has been read by dnsmasq, 
      then the host record it contained will remain until dnsmasq receives a 
      SIGHUP, or is restarted; ie host records are only added dynamically.
      <snip>

Instead of truncating the `host_file` in L122 it might be an option to set the ',ignore' flag for the nodes mac addresses. Then some periodic task to remove ',ignore' entries and do a HUP to ensure dnsmasq re-reads configuration from files. But I think any changing beyond adding opts for a node will require service HUP.

ironic/dhcp/dnsmasq.py.message: As much as periodics make me sad at times, I do think it is likely a good path to take for managing the files and contents, and would help ensure a drive towards eventual consistency.

> Wonder if generating a new uuid for the tag every time DHCP options are updated would be an alternative? i.e instead of the node-uuid which would be re-used each time a node is booted.

Yep, I think its time to store some state in the driver_internal_info of the node, just a unique UUID, so to summarize:

- the tag is a unique uuid stored in driver_internal_info, unset during clean_dhcp_opts
- the hosts filename has the mac address, applies the uuid tag, replaced with the ignore tag on clean_dhcp_opts
- the options filename is the *node* uuid, matching on the tag from the driver_internal_info uuid, deleted on clean_dhcp_opts

This results in no dnsmasq rules applying from previous actions, no requirement for SIGHUP, and the only accumulating files are hosts entries with mac address filenames that don't need any periodic delete.

The only thing the host record does is tag the mac with the node uuid. I don't think we ever want to ignore the mac because it might show up with a different node uuid. We probably don't need to care about the tagging lingering after cleanup and we could even delete the host file completely. (as long as a new tag gets applied when the same mac shows up with a different node uuid).

What we do need to think about is the behaviour of dhcp-optsdir rules disappearing and being overwritten. I might need to observe actual behaviour because the docs are too vague to make any kind of assertion.

Also I'd really like to avoid needing SIGHUP ever, because it would be very difficult to do that from outside the container in the kubernetes case. The only way I can think of is to write a dnsmasq process manager wrapper which spawns dnsmasq, does its own inotify watching, and sends SIGHUP when necessary. Then the systemd unit or pod launches the wrapper, not dnsmasq. (I should probably look at how neutron does it)

Edit:
We could go with Harald's host ',ignore' approach as long as update_dhcp_opts parses every existing file to delete files with a matching mac and the ignore tag before writing the new file. That seems do-able.

> > Wonder if generating a new uuid for the tag every time DHCP options are updated would be an alternative? i.e instead of the node-uuid which would be re-used each time a node is booted.
> 
> Yep, I think its time to store some state in the driver_internal_info of the node, just a unique UUID, so to summarize:
> 
> - the tag is a unique uuid stored in driver_internal_info, unset during clean_dhcp_opts
> - the hosts filename has the mac address, applies the uuid tag, replaced with the ignore tag on clean_dhcp_opts
> - the options filename is the *node* uuid, matching on the tag from the driver_internal_info uuid, deleted on clean_dhcp_opts
> 
> This results in no dnsmasq rules applying from previous actions, no requirement for SIGHUP, and the only accumulating files are hosts entries with mac address filenames that don't need any periodic delete.

Yes, Good idea using driver_internal_info!
I belive this implementation as detailed above will work.

We may want to document that busy environments should restart/SIGHUP the external dnsmasq periodically to avoid potential performance degradation in dnsmasq if the options in memory grow to a huge number. I can't imagine more often than daily or even weekly would be required, with such intervals asking the user to set up a cron job or similar seems reasonable.

I'd be open to more API based DHCP providers other than the neutron one, but I can't imagine metal3 or bifrost switching so the motivation would need to come from whoever has the use case.

Any HUP support is tricky due to the variety of ways the dnsmasq daemon is managed. We have systemd (bifrost), a container in a kubernetes pod (metal3) and a standalone container (metal3, dev-mode). This is why I've been motivated to stay away from requiring sending HUP at all.

The dnsmasq logging gives some reasonable transparency on what is happening:
https://storage.gra.cloud.ovh.net/v1/AUTH_dcaab5e32b234d56b626f72581e3644c/zuul_opendev_logs_e30/851682/6/check/bifrost-integration-redfish-uefi-fedora-latest/e30e80e/logs/dnsmasq.log

Gonna be honest, all this complexity makes me want to see what a real-api-accessible DHCP integration would look like (e.g. isc-dhcp-server or kea)... or even a small wrapper that could run alongside dnsmasq to hold some of this complexity (and perform HUPs is needed).

I don't love the solution as proposed as it'll make troubleshooting failed DHCP significantly harder than it already is, but I don't have a better suggestion that can maintain the requirement that we support situations where Ironic would be unable to HUP dnsmasq that also doesn't require a lot more work.

To summarize, imo this is OK to support dnsmasq; but also should be seen as evidence that dnsmasq may not be the best fit for our use case.

> What we do need to think about is the behaviour of dhcp-optsdir rules disappearing and being overwritten. I might need to observe actual behaviour because the docs are too vague to make any kind of assertion.
> 

+1 on observing actual behavior.

I believe options are essentially always add only when files in dhcp-optsdir is changed so in dnsmasq memory they are never overwritten. Multiple options for a tag is added like this:
dhcp-option=tag:uuid-aaa,option:OPT_A,VALUE_a
dhcp-option=tag:uuid-aaa,option:OPT_B,VALUE_b
dhcp-option=tag:uuid-aaa,option:OPT_C,VALUE_c

If we later do:
dhcp-option=tag:<uuid-aaa>,option:OPT_A,VALUE_a_new
dhcp-option=tag:<uuid-aaa>,option:OPT_C,Value_c_new

I don't think dnsmasq overwrites the previous OPT_A and OPT_C, I think the new value is simply appended to a linked list in dnsmasq memory and I'm not sure the actual value returned to a DHCP client is even deterministic in this case.


Wonder if generating a new uuid for the tag every time DHCP options are updated would be an alternative? i.e instead of the node-uuid which would be re-used each time a node is booted.
a tought ... would it be more efficient to use a hosts file per-mac address instead of a file per-node which may hold dnsmasq host entry for multiple macs?
That would save having to scan every file, yeah
Marking this resolved, current patch set has a file per-mac.

An idea, probably good as follow up patch to catch other peoples opinion.

Assuming the dnsmasq service is potentially shared, used for non-ironic case as well. Would it make sense to set an additional tag to indicate this is an ironic node, i.e 'set:ironic'? (Something configurable would probably be better)

This would allow the user to set options in dnsmasq.conf with tag:!ironic, (not) to ensure generic options never apply to ironic nodes?
If we do this, lets do it now rather than in a follow-up, so untagged entries never get created. I do think it's a good idea to namespace them, barring other complications.
Done

The approach to relation optionality needs to tie in with work on relation status as the two are quite closely linked.

Samuel and I chatted about having a flag in the relation handler to indicate whether the relation was optional or not, rather than having a list in the charm which details which ones are optional.

I prefer this approach as it means the relation handler can set appropriate relation status depending on whether its needed or not.

We probably should have metadata that the implementing charm can define about which relations are optional which could then be used to populate this flag in each relation handler - the default being 'mandatory'.

ops_sunbeam/charm.py.message:
Note from our discussion about modelling optional relations in the context of compound status - the state of a handler being optional or mandatory should be stored in the handler itself, passed in the constructor.

So the self.optional_relations set can be removed.  And the logic here can be something like `if handler.mandatory: return False`
I don't like that we have two sources of truth here: handler.optional and self.optional_relations.  It looks like we can drop the self.optional_relations set here?
Why can't the charms pass the `optional` argument to the constructor when initialising a relation handler?

> requires removing initialisation of certain relation handlers from library and do it in charm project. 

To be perfectly honest, this would be a great improvement.  I'm all in favour of composition over inheritance.

But alas we're kind of stuck in this deep inheritance pattern here already... ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

But yes:

> I'm fine with the class holding a list of optional relations; this can then be driven dynamically in the implementing charm class

this would have both: the set of optional relations defined as an attribute, and checking that attribute when constructing the handlers wherever (eg. `self.db = DBHandler(..., optional=('db' in self.optional_handlers))`)


> If we where to just have mandatory_relations, members of which could be relation groups, would that be more elegant?

I like this.

I concur with Samuel - it would be cleaner to pass this as an arg to the constructor for each relation handler rather than updating it afterward.

I'm fine with the class holding a list of optional relations; this can then be driven dynamically in the implementing charm class; I do have a bit of a question in my mind as to whether we should do this the other way around has having optional relations and the mandatory relation groups seems awkward.

If we where to just have mandatory_relations, members of which could be relation groups, would that be more elegant?

Some of the relation handlers defined and initialised in ops_sunbeam library are optional for some charms and mandatory for other charms. To make `optional` argument as part of the constructor requires removing initialisation of certain relation handlers from library and do it in charm project. Example, amqp is optional for glance but mandatory for most of the other sunbeam charms.

Also `optional_relations` gives a nice single place for knowing optional relations. Any new optional relations added in future can be just updated at a single place.
self.optional_relations is required to update handler.optional. This gives flexibility for individual charms to set which relations are optional.
you could dynamically generate a list of handler which are mandatory here rather than iterating all of them.
Modelling this as mandatory relations might make this cleaner as well.

cinder/volume/flows/manager/create_volum.message:
It seems format='json' makes the encrypted attribute set to true/false instead of 'yes'/None.

I'm waiting for feedback in the bug I reported for oslo.utils[1], but I think the current approach here, rather than checking the actual value, would be more simple but reliable.

[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/oslo.utils/+bug/1942682

Note that this logic is still compatible even with human format, because qemu-img info doesn't show the "encrypted" like if the image is non-encrypted, which results in None.

The possible patterns it can return is
 'yes' / None  -> format raw or format json with recent oslo.utils
 true  / false -> format json, with older oslo.utils
so there is not chance(at least until now).
It has never returned 'no' because of behavior of qemu-img and now because of the logic in oslo.utils.

we can implement something like

  if strutils.bool_from_string(image_info.encrypted, False):

but I feel this is a bit redundant considering we never expect false strings.
It was fixed in the latest oslo.utils but I tend to just leave this as it is to keep the logic more simple.

OK, I looked at your patch that fixed this in oslo.utils, and it seems pretty clear from the commit message and release note that the contract for the encrypted field is that the values are either 'yes' or None.  So what you have here should be fine.

I was thinking about this some more, and I think I want to insist on changing the condition to

  # see Bug #1942682 and Change I949f07582a708 for why we do this
  if strutils.bool_from_string(image_info.encrypted):

it looks like overkill, but this way we're covered for all the obvious boolean and quasi-boolean values (including None) that might be in that field.

Thanks. Adding that note sound reasonable. Updated the patch accordingly. Note that bool_from_string doesn't accept None unless we define the default, and that's why the latest implementation is a bit different.
This looks like a bugfix for a different issue that shouldn't be apart of this patch.

This is to workaround the issue with old oslo.utils, which was discovered by the switch to json format. (in old oslo.utils this returns true instead of 'yes' when json format is used.

We no longer need this change because the issue was fixed in recent oslo.utils, but I decided to add this as the safe guard as suggested by Brian earlier. Please check our discussions in patch set 7.

I need to get a better grasp on the 'whys'...

We don't need to pre-emptively patch the logging._lock because it will get patched retrospectively by the eventlet patcher when eventlet_monkey_patch is called...so does this imply we should not use eventlet threads with logging unless we've eventlet_monkey_patch'ed?

We don't need to patch logging.threading because we don't try to log threads.

We don't need to patch logging.thread because (a) it py2 only and (b) we don't try to log threads.

But I'm not sure why we don't still need to patch logging.threading for the handler locks?
mostly because we don't do a lot of runtime reconfiguraiton of loggers - but also because logging to syslog over udp can't interleave so it's naturally serialized w/o the need for a lock.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
I think swift will continue to run fine on py2 and py3 with this change - and it will be importable without breaking logging and giving you a bunch of eventlet tracebacks even if the code importing swift.common.utils helpers has a totally different concurrency framework.

If stopping doing the bad thing causes any real problems that would be a (surprising) bug - and we would fix it w/o any evil import side effects.

I am not concerned about correct thread_id logging or the locks created in the logging module - swift doesn't do any concurrent manipulation of logging handlers/etc during runtime and the only handler we *do* care about (our syslog handler) uses a big fat pipe mutex so we can log across greenthreads and os threads w/o anyone blocking each other.

I know change can be scary - that's why this has stayed this way so long.  We need to land this change and move forward.

I think we managed to wait this one out, i'm not aware of any issues we still need to work around with eventlet and stdlib logging module level imports anymore.

This change has no effect on swift's logging in practice/production and is a long requested quality of life imporovement for anyone importing swift.common modules into non-eventlet based projects.
I'll also try to add a test for the logThreadId being disabled

we should probably patch "thread" in the daemons; maybe we could go ahead and do socket too just to keep it consistent, but it probably doesn't matter cause we always use explicit green sockets (but it *might* be relevant just cause "patching thread" is the best way to "fix logging")
(BTW I think this is safe to re-check)
should we also be adding a call to eventlet_monkey_patch in internal_client, or do we assume that anywhere it is used should take care of that?

FWIW, 1space does this already, but the inventory service does not. Not sure how much other external code we know about. Probably not a bad idea to call it, yeah?

I think it probably isn't necessary if you've got something like the MultiprocessInternalClient from https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/swift/+/803536, but I don't think it'd really hurt, either. Right?

Alistair's follow-up *might* be enough to sway me -- but I've still got some nervousness about just *delaying* the lock monkey-patching... at the same time, I don't particularly want to continue patching stdlib forever :-(

Maybe this is fine?
I squahed in the py3 explicit patch

swift/common/utils.py.message: this doesn't even exist in py3
I think the eventlet ad-hoc fix and our explicit patch of the module global make this a moot point

Does our dropping it mean that things no longer work on py2, though? We're going to drop it this cycle, but I want to make sure we're clear on *when* that happens, and signal it via packaging metadata before we actually start breaking things for py2.

AFAICT the import of thread in py2.7 logging is only used to test if the import succeeded, and if logThreads is True, which we set False in eventlet_monkey_patch i.e. logging.thread is tested for existence but logging.thread members are not accessed if eventlet_monkey_patch has been called
this is mostly for threading.get_ident/get_current - but we turn off logThreads https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/swift/+/752593
i have tests that assert we turn off logThreads

it's also used to instantiate threading.RLock instances, one of which is logging._lock covered on next line, but also when creating handlers

Also, since we'll rely more on https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/swift/+/752593, perhaps we should have test coverage for it (AFAICT it is not covered)

this is mostly used for module level initialization stuff (like removeing handlers) but regardless eventlet takes care of it for us:

https://github.com/eventlet/eventlet/commit/bbeaa2e3a0b6da26af08f5e6734767e04c187c5b
i pulled in the py3 fix and our no-lock-logging test demonstrated it doesn't really matter anyway.

And we dragged forward our eventlet requirement a while back to include that (among other things): https://github.com/openstack/swift/commit/0ebfeddf65adb473fda2adfd1705534b6308cd2b

A little more color on the patching: https://github.com/eventlet/eventlet/pull/743

Not that what we do here had any impact on that particular bug. Reminds me that I should bug temoto for a release that includes the fix, though ;-)

IIUC the eventlet patch fixes up existing instances of RLock, e.g. logging._lock would be patched if logging has been imported before we call eventlet_monkey_patch.

But, with this change applied, that leaves future instantiations of logging.threading.RLock() unpatched...don't we still need 

  logging.threading = eventlet.green.threading

somewhere, to patch the locks that might be created for logging handlers?

I'm getting worried now -- I think this may be the only thing saving us from https://github.com/eventlet/eventlet/issues/546 -- it sure seems like eventlet can't find the locks it needs to green on (at least) py36-39.

I got a patch up to make it work on py310, though -- https://github.com/eventlet/eventlet/pull/754

Still nervous about this, for a few reasons:

- It's not clear to me how things will fail if we still need it but we take it out.
- I'm not at all convinced that any failure mode would be obvious or easy to debug.
- Lock monkey-patching is known-broken on py3.
- This monkey-patching has been present *since the beginning*, so we don't even have the benefit of some commit message or review back-and-forth to give us a hint as to what the goal is, or how things fail without it.

Something about this logic strikes me wrong. Threads and locks must always be consistent is what I believe. So, it makes no sense to stop greening locks of logging forcefully yet substitute the threading. Granted I didn't think about it as deep as Alistair did, but it looks fishy.
this is really only for py3 - for py2 eventlet already does this

Because we're dealing with delimiters here and the marker ends in a delimiter. Should this rather be marker + '\x00', becuase the rest of the psudo filesystem could under the current marker could span more then a shard? Ie:

  $ curl -X GET <blah>/v1/a/c?prefix=photos/&marker=photos/&delimiter=/
  photos/animals/     <- shard 1
  photos/people/      <- shard 2
  photos/plants/      <- shard 3

In this case, the next_possible_name would become photos0, so would skip the first 2 shards and only talk to shard 3, assuming it contains the namespace to the end.

No, that's the optimization -- (marker + '\x00') all the way through (marker + '\xff' * BIGNUM) are all going to be contained "within" that marker entry that we already found from the previous shard range.

If we've got no prefix and some shards like

 '' through 'foo/bar'
 'foo/bar' through 'foo/baz'
 'foo/baz' through ''

then once we get back 'foo/' from the first shard, there's no reason to query the second shard at all; 'foo/' is the only result we could hope to get from it. So, skip it and go straight to the third shard.

I'll write up some tests to demonstrate it.

This isn't sufficient -- we need to consider prefix. Or rather, we need to track whether last_name was an object entry or a subdir entry.

In particular, try making a container with some (pathologically named) objects:

 x/
 x//
 x///
 x////

and shards that only have one object, so ranges like:

 ''     - 'x/'
 'x/'   - 'x//'
 'x//'  - 'x///'
 'x///' - ''

Do a query like `?delimiter=//&prefix=x//` -- we'll

* skip the first shard, since it can't contain the prefix
* find an object record for 'x//' from the second shard (but here we assume it was a subdir!)
* skip the third shard since 'x///' starts with our last_name, 'x//'
* find a subdir entry 'x////' from the last shard

causing us to miss 'x///'.

---

Oh! Even simpler repro; no multi-character delimiter required: given a listing like

 x/
 x/y/z
 y

and shard ranges like

 ''      - 'x/'
 'x/'    - 'x/y/z'
 'x/y/z' - ''

then `?delimiter=/&prefix=x/` will miss the 'x/y/' subdir.

Further, because it ends in delimiter we can assume it's a subdir.. but that means that there was an object (most likely) that is bigger then the last object (because it's a subdir, ie if the subdir is foo/ then in the shard before there must've been a foo/<plus_something>. So how could the next range .upper be foo/? foo is smaller then foo/<plus_something>.

Everytime I come to subdir and pseudo folders, I always miss something obvious, just can't get the damn thing in my head. What am I missing?

Mostly, this was because I couldn't remember how delimiter listings work ;-)

> because it ends in delimiter we can assume it's a subdir

This was the assumption I was questioning -- specifically, if you have a container with objects

 obj
 subdir/
 subdir/obj

then issue a ?delimiter=/ query, I couldn't remember whether we'd get one or *two* entries for subdir/ -- turns out it's just the one, and the object "subdir/" doesn't show up until you do a ?delimiter=/&prefix=subdir/ query.

I think we can just drop this clause -- it'll be a good bit cleaner and no less correct.

How comfortable are we with delaying this? It seems like we're widening the window in which some code may get a hold of a reference to the non-green lock... do we have any feel for how sideways things will go if there's code with a stale lock reference?

I think we could make an argument to perform the same treatment on:

    pyeclib.ec_iface.syslog_handler.lock

i've said before that I understand logging._lock as being entirely used by the logging module to control concurrent access to the global logging state (configured loggers and handlers) so that it's threadsave to call methods like "removeHandler"

I'm not worried AT ALL about this lock because we setup logging very simply and early, before we start any (green|tpool|os)threads, and then we don't reconfigure anything again.

If py3 leaves the os thread reentrent lock in place two greenthreads trying to reconfigure logging could in theory manage to trigger a race condition that corrupts thread state (all greenthreads are "allowed" to have the reentrent lock because they're on the same os thread) - but only if the logging module itself ALSO managed to tramponline while iterating the list of handlers or whatever.  So... I'm not worried AT ALL about this lock.

swift/container/backend.py.message:
I don't think container-sync will work with a sharded DB (no more rows will land in the fresh db except misplaced updates).

However, similar to reconciler_sync_point comment below - I don't think it matters what value these sync points have in the fresh_db as long as they are less than max_row, but reasonable to copy from the retiring db.

OK, so the replicator dump_to_reconciler() method looks for misplaced object rows with row id greater than reconciler_sync_point. The fresh db has no object row ids less than the retiring db max_row, so the reconciler will find no misplaced rows between reconciler_sync_point and max_row. The fresh_db's reconciler_sync_point could therefore be any value between 0 and max_row - it makes no difference - but copying the value from retiring db is reasonable.

Hey Arx, not sure if this is work in progress or ready for review.

Voted -1 simply to mark this patch as "requires more work".

Some thoughts:

* Use Gerrit's work-in-progress feature to mark the status of the patch. A minus workflow (-w) will be reset when a new patchset is uploaded and hence easy to miss.

* Version checks are no longer necessary since we globally require openstacksdk >=0.99.0 anyway.

* When a id is given in XXX_info modules, then we do not need nor want extra code to handle that. Instead most openstacksdk resources allow to pass ids as query arguments to openstack api. For example, identity.identity_providers() can be used for both cases: Where an id is given and where no id is given. No need to call get_identity_provider().

* self.params.get('...') can be replaced with self.params['...'] because parameters from argument_spec will always be in self.params. If not defined differently, they have a default value of None.

* Add assertions on module results

* Function normalize_mapping() is obsolete and can be dropped.

* Check description of module attribute 'name'

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: Straightforward enough, just found one small thing

Thank you, Arx! 

Voted -1 simply to mark this patch as "requires more work".

Some thoughts on this patch, this time in a single comment ;)

* openstacksdk does no longer return Munch objects. It returns resources which we convert to dictionaries, so we have to update RETURN docs in most modules.

* RETURN doc is missing the id attribute

* openstacksdk functions often accept IDs but no names, e.g. find_address_scope() and create_address_scope() accept a project_id parameter. Most modules in our collection use names for finding resources, so we want to support the same for resources attributes such as project_id in AddressScope.

This module allows that already: It takes a project parameter which is then used to find projects. But it is not consistently used, e.g. it should also be passed to find_address_scope() when searching for address scopes.

* Since ID is already part of the resource dict that is returned by the module, we can safely drop dedicated id attributes in self.exit_json() calls. We will not loose data and we break backward compatibility anyway.



The following list of suggestion is optional:

* Replacing self.conn.get_* with self.conn.*.find_* functions allows us to specify a "ignore_missing=False" parameter. That allows us to drop our self.fail_json() calls in our modules. Less code, less to maintain ;)

* When you rename option names to the attribute names that openstacksdk uses, then it is easier to use for users since both inputs and outputs of a module match. Example: shared => is_shared

* When list of expected module results is moved to role defaults (e.g. as expected_fields), it is easier to reuse.

* Sorting module options in DOCUMENTATION, attributes in RETURN, entries in argument_spec and expected fields in integration tests will make reviewing easier and faster.

* Having code to check that some options cannot be updated and to fail if user still tries to update that value is most often not worth it. It would require much more code to catch all cases where updates are impossible and we would have to implement it consistently across modules. Atm we are fine with documenting which attribute cannot be updated in DOCUMENTATION variable.

In particular, 'Cannot update ip_version in existing address scope' is nice but incomplete: We cannot update any attribute except (is_)shared. IMHO we could simply drop this check and insert a sentence to DOCUMENTATION that ip_version cannot be updated. We do the same for server modules and others.
I guess everything is addressed on the new patchset

releasenotes/notes/bug-1968164-cinder-ma.message: Please drop this file. This would be confusing to someone reading the release notes.

-1: Thank you for including a release note, it's a very important aspect of fixing bugs and many times we forget it.  The important aspect of a release note is that the intended audience are system administrators, and this message is too developer focused.

You should phrase the release note in a way that they would know what has been fixed.  This is just a suggestion, but maybe on the lines of: "Fixed cinder reporting incorrect volume size when cache is enabled and the image is smaller than the created volume."

releasenotes/notes/bug-1968164-powerflex.message:
-1: The note should start with the driver name:

  PowerFlex driver `bug #1968164 <https://bugs.

A few grammatical things here that should be fixed.

Maybe something like:

> Fixed the display of the incorrect volume size on volume or snapshot creation. PowerFlex storage requires volumes sizes to be a multiple of 8 GiB. This size was being reported to the end user, potentially causing confusion by being different than what they requested.

At a bare minimum, don't refer to the user as "him".

fun, here it was working just fine without the .service... I'll do some more tests.

@Takashi: if you don't have enough work, please, lemme know, I have a ton of ideas :D

Ah, also, intended action:
- rc == 0, means the unit is present, in whatever state we get
- rc == 1, means the unit is not present

We don't want to fail on [0, 1]

Then, if we match rc == 0, then we want to ensure it's enabled/running/configured.

This is the intended use, and your listing seems to show it's working as expected. I'm adding the ".service", indeed it's needed. And will also make sure it's working fine if anyone copies this logic for a service with some alias.

I somehow misread the return code but indeed the return code is different if the service does not exist. I was thinking of using systemctl status intead but it'd be
overkilling as it can show a few more different codes.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
The jammy-yoga test fails with an install hook failure for ovn-dedicated-chassis due to:

ERROR: Could not find a version that satisfies the requirement setuptools>=42 (from versions: 41.6.0)
ERROR: No matching distribution found for setuptools>=42 

It seems the problem is that the wheelhouse.txt python_version checks are not working as expected.

I was able to get beyond the install hook failure locally by modifying the wheelhouse.txt in https://github.com/juju-solutions/layer-basic to remove all of the python_version logic such that it implicitly supported py310 only. E.g.

-setuptools<42;python_version < '3.8'
-# https://github.com/juju-solutions/layer-basic/issues/201
-setuptools<62.2.0;python_version >= '3.8'
-setuptools-scm<=1.17.0;python_version < '3.8'
-# https://github.com/pypa/setuptools_scm/issues/722
-setuptools-scm<7;python_version >= '3.8'
-flit_core;python_version >= '3.8'
+setuptools<62.2.0
+setuptools-scm<7
+flit_core

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
Thank you, Ananya 😊

Voted -1 simply to mark this patch as "requires more work".

Some thoughts:
* Version checks are no longer necessary since we globally require openstacksdk >=0.99.0 anyway.

* When you rename option names to the attribute names that openstacksdk uses, then you can replace most of the filters code with a for loop. It is also easier to use if both inputs and outputs of a module match. But add old option names as aliases to keep backward compatibility. This has patch for floating_ip_info has some ideas for how to write those loops: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/ansible-collections-openstack/+/828613

* Some modules have branches with special handling when a name is given. We can drop that because in most (all?) modules we can simply pass the name as a query parameter. Behind the scenes openstacksdk is doing the same api calls anyway.

* Some modules do not use "name" for resource names, e.g. port module had an attribute called "port" instead of "name". We rename those attributes to "name" to be consistent in our modules and because openstacksdk doing the same. But we add the old attribute as an alias to keep backward compatibility.

* Replacing self.conn.get_* with self.conn.*.find_* functions allows us to specify a "ignore_missing=False" parameter. That allows us to drop our self.fail_json() calls in our modules. Less code, less to maintain ;)

* Some modules pass ignore_missing=True to self.conn.*.find_* functions and then fail if the return value is None. Most often that does not make sense and is redundant code. Just switching True to False helps us to drop code.

* When you come across a module attribute that has choices, always doubt the possible values. The module code was probably written long ago and thus the choices might be horrible outdated. Sometimes it makes sense to get rid of the choices because the choices are simply to narrow and might soon be outdated again.

* Check old comments and see if they are still relevant.

* Do sanity check argument_spec and module_kwargs. Some modules try to be clever and add checks to fail early instead of letting openstacksdk or OpenStack API handle incompatible arguments.

* When you edit a patch, first rebase your patch on top of the current branch. Sometimes we replace code in all modules which might cause merge conflicts for you otherwise. For example, we dropped all options with default values from argument_spec such as "required=False".

* Do sanity check existing integration tests. For example, when a module is called, then often at least basic tests should be done but existing code is sometimes missing these checks.



I am trying to improve my feedback, so please share what you think about the style of my review above.

Ack for removing version check, loop for filters, replacing get with find and ignore missing false, removing choices.

I could not figure out these two:
- Some modules have branches with special handling when a name is given. We can drop that because in most (all?) modules we can simply pass the name as a query parameter. Behind the scenes openstacksdk is doing the same api calls anyway.
- Some modules do not use "name" for resource names, e.g. port module had an attribute called "port" instead of "name". We rename those attributes to "name" to be consistent in our modules and because openstacksdk doing the same. But we add the old attribute as an alias to keep backward compatibility.

Does self.conn.network.security_group_rules(**filters) take care of rule, project and security group (because in this module we have branches for these 3)?
Thank you 😊 i think we got them all ^^

Cool! 

For direction and ether_type/ethertype we can keep choices since it is very unlikely those to change anytime soon. Removing choices on protocol makes sense because those choices were too narrow.

> - Some modules have branches with special handling when a name is given. We can drop that because in most (all?) modules we can simply pass the name as a query parameter. Behind the scenes openstacksdk is doing the same api calls anyway.

The module branches off for module attribute 'rule' and exits early (it will exit in middle of run()). This whole branch is not necessary because we can simply pass the contents of 'rule' as a query parameter 'id' [1] to OpenStack API.

> - Some modules do not use "name" for resource names, e.g. port module had an attribute called "port" instead of "name". We rename those attributes to "name" to be consistent in our modules and because openstacksdk doing the same. But we add the old attribute as an alias to keep backward compatibility.

For this module we would rename 'rule' to 'name' in order to be consistent with other modules. [Actually security group rules do not have names, only ids, but openstacksdk also has this inaccuracy, e.g. allowing to search for security group rules by name_or_id in network.find_security_group_rule().]

> Does self.conn.network.security_group_rules(**filters) take care of rule, project and security group (because in this module we have branches for these 3)?

For project and security group we have to keep the special handling because have to resolve names to ids for both. But 'rule' we can simply pass as 'id' in filters [1].

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/openstacksdk/src/branch/master/openstack/network/v2/security_group_rule.py#L30

I take it all back, sorry. It does indeed work as described.

Maybe a single line letting the user know that we're rendering templates would be a nice middle ground though?

One minor problem with this. But overall, I like the direction. There is a fine line between informative information, and drowning the user in too much information to comb through should something fail.
i feel like if there is an error, this isn't an improvement. Having to reproduce manually feels like a regression in UX. Could we save the output and display it only if there is an error?

I guess we could only log if there's an error? Sadly the way this all works: we're shelling out to another tool which doesn't take care of logging. All the stdout is returned as a WARNING log message which is both too verbose and misleading.

I see the current output as mostly useless; it's a mess mixed with ansible/tripleo/and random tools. With this change a user will know what failed and how to reproduce it, which will generate useful log information if required.

If the logs are too verbose to our liking, why not change in the script[1] itself to remove or use add --debug flag to print those?

[1] https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/master/tools/process-templates.py#L82
    https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/master/tools/process-templates.py#L307

I think we should do this too. However, I'd like to also start refactoring how we execute and external scripts / binaries from within the client; mostly so we're not always logging warnings for all of a given script's stdout.

i'm fine to see if there other opinions on this one. I feel that we should always show errors, and that the current behavior (while not great), is better in that it will show the error without having to reproduce the failure.

Care to explain that specific volume usage?

This allows the home directory of the execution user to be accessible within the execution environment which ensure the ansible runtime has access to all of the expected templates, logs, config files, etc.

also worth noting that the container see this as "root" which is translated on the host as "$USER" so it shouldn't break permissions as they stand. It'll be interesting to figure out what the selinux implications are.
Does this override only for localhost, or for all hosts? I'm not seeing any guards here to make sure this doesn't mess with non-localhost but it could be that this is done in ansible itself?
Good catch, this should be done when running in a venv and targeting localhost.
Isn't this the default? Why is this necessary? Could we get this for free some other way (like ensuring that the container inherits some environment variables or something)?
It is default when facts are gathered, however, those initial facts may be that of the container, so this sets the home folder accordingly for our cli-* playbooks.

Hi. Thanks for the patch. Unfortunately I did find couple of issues while testing it on 16.2.

Most importantly, the inventories generated with new, and original admin config differ in more substantial ways. Some host groups are added and others missing.

Also validations seem to have issues reaching overcloud hosts, if the newly generated inventory is used.

I can't recommend merging this patch, unless we can figure out how to restore this functionality.

Finally, is there a bug we could link this too? BZ or LP?

Linking inventory diff in pastebin. The inventory was generated for a temporary dev environment. So the information is not of security value. However I've redacted the auth deets just in case. 



http://pastebin.test.redhat.com/1067031

Can you make sure you paste the outputs with both users separately? I can't make out anything from that diff.

>  To reiterate, I don't see any bug referenced, so I have no context as to why is this change needed. Especially on a stable branch.

Because the default is tripleo-admin and this default in tripleo-validation is inconsistent. Though I don't care much what you guys do. There can be issues when deploy runs with one user and validation generates inventory with another user and someone uses it for running playbooks.

I do. The difference unfortunately goes beyond the user credentials. I'm putting the diff in public pastebin this time.

While this is indeed an upstream review, the change would eventually land in downstream, so any changes in that behavior are important. To reiterate, I don't see any bug referenced, so I have no context as to why is this change needed. Especially on a stable branch.

https://paste.opendev.org/show/bb77c2E4Qz7IijFn0UDx/

@jpodvin

Do you still see issues with the generated inventory with two different users? Can you use the tripleoclient patch and share the inventories for both.

Why would the inventories generated be different? Check the inventory in upstream train, it uses tripleo-admin[1][2]. As for not being able to reach overcloud nodes with newly generated inventory, it was broken in train and fixed with[3] and has not yet made it to downstream.

It's weird that validation is not using the tripleo default and I don't think there should be any issues.


[1] https://storage.gra.cloud.ovh.net/v1/AUTH_dcaab5e32b234d56b626f72581e3644c/zuul_opendev_logs_9e9/850236/3/gate/tripleo-ci-centos-8-containers-multinode/9e9d1cc/logs/undercloud/var/lib/mistral/config-download-latest/tripleo-ansible-inventory.yaml
[2] https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-common/blob/stable/train/tripleo_common/actions/ansible.py#L732
[3] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/python-tripleoclient/+/850236

Note:  This is an upstream review which does not have any context of what 16.2 is and the paste you linked is an internal link. Please use https://paste.opendev.org/

> Unfortunately that still leaves me with authentication issues when I'm trying to run validations with it.

I think I mentioned that earlier too. Did you deploy/re-deploy 16.2 with https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/python-tripleoclient/+/850236?
Phew..@Adriano use  https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/python-tripleoclient/+/850236 to deploy 16.2 or test upstream stable/train.

I think I owe you an apology, and retraction. It appears the diff was polluted by order of the keys, which should have been accounted for. The patch changes just the user.

Unfortunately that still leaves me with authentication issues when I'm trying to run validations with it.

Reordered invs:
https://paste.opendev.org/show/baDzaZEK5Ykach2dhFA1/
https://paste.opendev.org/show/b76xnxMEoGhTr4jHY88i/

Is there somewhere else that is missing for tripleo-admin to have the right privilegies or is there something different that we need to do with tripleo-admin for it to be an equivalent replacement.

inventory/group_vars/hosts.yml.message: to drop that you would need to patch hardening role. It still does not have default of package_state unlike the other roles.

AFAIK it doesn't need a patch, cause it was never intended for that.
The intention for hardening was to have it stay in "present" (which is the current default in the role). As the OSA policy was to have it "latest", it needed wiring to match the existing policy, which is what you see here.

If the policy is to be "present", then security_package_state doesn't need overriding. I could create security_package_state: "{{ security_package_state | default(package_state) | default('present') }}" in the play if you like, but I don't see it as relevant. It can definitely be done in a follow up commit if necessary.
actually all these should be patched to respect `package_state`

Yes, indeed. I am moving them one by one, evaluating their history first.
I then add them to the depends-on.
